intro: Hjaltalinia villosa, commonly known as the Arctic bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Arctic and subarctic regions. It is characterized by its hairy, low-growing stems and showy blue or purple flowers that bloom in the summer. The plant thrives in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to cold, harsh environments. Its leaves are typically linear and covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss in its arid habitat. Hjaltalinia villosa plays an important role in the alpine ecosystem, providing nectar for pollinators and contributing to the biodiversity of its region.
